slides.title: Learning Objectives
content: At the end of this tutorial, you will be able to:

List common file types and their extensions.
narration: By the end of this session, you will achieve these objectives.
You will define files and directories.
You will distinguish between them clearly.
Also, you will list various common file types.
Point 1.

slides.title: Prerequisites
content: Basic computer literacy.
Familiarity with a graphical user interface (GUI).
narration: To get the most from this tutorial, you should know some basics.
You should know how to use a computer.
Also, some familiarity with any operating system's interface helps.

slides.title: System Requirements
content: Any modern operating system (Windows, Linux, macOS).
A working computer with internet access (optional).
narration: You will need a computer with any common operating system.
Windows, Linux, or macOS will all work fine.
No special software installation is required.

slides.title: Files and Directories: A Library Analogy
content: Imagine a library to understand files and directories.
Books in the library are like files.
Shelves and sections are like directories.
They help organize all the books (files).
narration: Let us use a simple example to understand these terms.
Think of a big library.
In this library, each book is like a computer file.
Books hold information, just like files do.
The shelves holding these books are like directories or folders.
slides.image_prompt: An illustration of a classic library interior, with bookshelves filled with books. One book is highlighted, and one shelf is highlighted.

slides.title: What are Files?
content: A file is a collection of related information.
It stores data on a computer system.
Examples: text documents, images, videos, programs.
Files have names and extensions (e.g., .txt, .jpg, .mp4).
narration: So, what exactly is a file?
A file is basically a container for information.
It holds data like your school notes or photos.
Files can be many things: a text document, a picture, or a video.
Even the programs you run are files.
slides.image_prompt: A montage of various file icons: a text document, a JPEG image, an MP4 video, and a generic program executable icon. Each has a clear name and extension.

slides.title: What are Directories?
content: A directory, also called a folder, organizes files.
It can also contain other directories (subfolders).
This creates a hierarchical structure.
Helps in managing and locating files efficiently.
narration: Now, let's talk about directories.
A directory is like a container for files.
We also call them folders, which is a more common term.
Folders help you keep your files neatly arranged.
You can even put folders inside other folders.
slides.image_prompt: An illustration showing a parent folder icon open, revealing several file icons and two smaller folder (subfolder) icons inside. This demonstrates hierarchy.

slides.title: Distinguishing Files and Directories
content: Files store actual data (e.g., text, images, code).
Directories store other files and directories.
Files have contents you can open and view.
Directories contain items, they do not have viewable 'content'.
narration: Let's see the main differences between them.
Files contain the actual data, like your written essay.
Directories, on the other hand, hold other files and folders.
When you open a file, you see its content.
When you open a directory, you see what is inside it.
slides.image_prompt: A split screen or side-by-side comparison. Left: a document file icon with content partially visible. Right: an open folder icon showing smaller file and folder icons within it.

slides.title: Summary
content: Files store specific data (documents, images).
Directories (folders) organize files and other directories.
The file extension indicates its type (e.g., .pdf, .mp3).
This organization helps manage computer data.
narration: Let's quickly recap what we learned.
Files are where your actual data resides.
Directories, or folders, are for organizing these files.
File extensions help us identify the file type.
Understanding this structure is key to using your computer efficiently.
slides.image_prompt: A clean, minimalist slide with three concise bullet points summarizing the key differences and roles of files and directories. A checkmark icon next to the title.

slides.title: Assignment
content: 1. Create a new folder named 'MyDocuments' on your desktop.
2. Inside 'MyDocuments', create a new text file named 'MyNotes.txt'.
3. Open 'MyNotes.txt' and type one sentence. Save the file.
4. Identify one common image file type and its extension.
narration: Now, it's time for a small practice assignment.
First, create a new folder on your desktop called MyDocuments.
Next, inside this folder, create a new text file.
Name this text file MyNotes.txt.
Open MyNotes.txt, type any single sentence, then save it.
